subsection.title: Introducing Polar Coordinates
subsection.p: We typically use Cartesian or rectangular coordinates to plot points. However, this can lead to issues if we have a graph that isn't rectangular. For example, the circle has a simple geometric description based on its center and radius, but in Cartesian coordinates it can be difficult to work with since every point on the (unit) circle takes the form (x,\pm\sqrt{1-x^{2}}). This square root makes integrals and derivatives complicated. The main problem lies in the fact that we are trying to describe a circle using a rectangular coordinate system. So our goal in this section is to find a more suitable coordinate system for circles.
A circle can be described as the set of all points some fixed distance r from a given point, and we can specify any point on the circle by using an angle \theta:

figure.caption: Using distance and angle to specify a point.

subsection.p: Any point P on the circle can be described solely using the distance r and the direction \theta. This leads directly to the idea of polar coordinates. In polar coordinates, the xy-plane is replaced with an r\theta-plane, or polar plane. Each point in the polar plane has the form (r,\theta), where the radial coordinate r denotes the distance from the origin, or pole, and the angular coordinate \theta determines the angle the point makes with the horizontal polar axis. The polar axis replaces the positive x-axis from Cartesian coordinates:

In polar coordinates, positive \theta correspond to counterclockwise direction, and negative \theta correspond to clockwise direction. We also allow for r to be negative: this just means go in the direction opposite of \theta.

example.title: Plotting polar coordinates
example.p: Suppose we want to plot the points (3,\pi), (-2,\frac{\pi}{4}) and (2,\frac{5\pi}{4}). We can do so in the polar plane by remembering that the first coordinate is distance from the pole, and the second coordinate is direction from the polar axis. If we plot these points, we see that (-2,\frac{\pi}{4}) and (2,\frac{5\pi}{4}) actually represent the same point. This is typical of polar coordinates: every point has, in general, infinitely many representations.

subsection.title: Polar Curves
subsection.p: Now we move on to graphing polar equations.

example.title: Graphs of constants in polar coordinates
example.p: In Cartesian coordinates, the graphs of x=a and y=a give horizontal and vertical lines, respectively. In polar coordinates, the graphs of r=a and \theta=a have simple descriptions as well. The graph of r=a is just the set of all points a units away from the pole, so it's just a circle of radius |a| centered at the pole. Likewise, the graph of \theta = a is the set of all points that make an angle of a with the polar axis, so it's just a line through the pole.

example.title: Graphs from Cartesian equations
example.p: In some cases it's beneficial to convert a polar equation to a Cartesian equation. The Cartesian equation may have a recognizable form that helps us to identify the corresponding polar graph. For example, suppose we want to describe the graph of r = 2a\sin\theta for some constant a. Then we can convert it to a Cartesian equation, in particular

If we complete the square, we get x^{2}+(y-a)^{2} = a^{2}, which describes a circle centered at (0,a) (in the xy-plane) and with radius |a|. In the polar plane, this is a circle of radius |a| centered at (a,\frac{\pi}{2}). Similarly, r=2a\cos\theta describes a circle of radius |a| centered at (a,0).

subsection.title: Areas of Polar Curves
subsection.p: To find the area of a region swept out by a polar curve, we need to reinvent the integral so to speak. In Cartesian coordinates, the integral was based on using rectangles to approximate areas. For polar coordinates, it makes more sense to use circular sectors.

statement.p: Suppose that R is a region bounded by the polar curves r=f(\theta) and r=g(\theta) between \theta = \alpha and \theta=\beta. If f and g are continuous and f(\theta)\geq g(\theta) for \alpha\leq\theta\leq\beta, then the area of R is given by \int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\frac{1}{2}[f(\theta)^{2}-g(\theta)^{2}]\,d\theta.

subsection.title: Arc Length in Polar Coordinates
subsection.p: Our goal now is to find the length of a polar curve r=f(\theta). From we know how to find the length of a parametric curve, and a polar curve is really just a parametric curve with parametric equations
subsection.me: x = r\cos\theta = f(\theta)\cos\theta \quad\text{and}\quad y = r\sin\theta = f(\theta)\sin\theta.
subsection.p: Using the formula L = \int_{a}^{b}\sqrt{(\dv{x}{\theta})^{2}+(\dv{y}{\theta})^{2}}\,d\theta and simplifying, we get the following result.

theorem.title: Arc Length of a Polar Curve

statement.p: The length L of a polar curve r = f(\theta) from \theta=a to \theta=b is given by L = \int_{a}^{b}\sqrt{r^{2} + \left(\dv{r}{\theta}\right)^{2}}\,d\theta.
